title: Social Work Group Practice Exam Set 1
description: Comprehensive examination covering social group work concepts, practices, and applications. Set 1 of 3. All questions written in clear, student-friendly language with practical examples and step-by-step explanations.

questions.question: According to the document, social group work (SGW) is defined as:

options.A: A method of social work which helps individuals enhance their social functioning through purposeful group experiences
options.B: A therapy technique focused solely on individual counseling

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: A** - A method of social work which helps individuals enhance their social functioning through purposeful group experiences

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **B** (A therapy technique focused solely on individual counseling) - This focuses on individuals rather than understanding how the whole group develops and changes.
• **C** (A community organization strategy) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (A case management approach) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a "formed group"?

options.A: Groups that develop naturally through mutual attraction
options.B: Groups that meet because of external influence with support for a specific purpose
options.C: Groups without any structure or purpose
options.D: Groups that exist only in therapeutic settings

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Groups that meet because of external influence with support for a specific purpose

**Why this is correct:** Understanding the difference between groups that form naturally (like friends) versus groups that are created by someone else (like therapy groups) helps social workers use the right approach for each type.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Groups that develop naturally through mutual attraction) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Groups without any structure or purpose) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Groups that exist only in therapeutic settings) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Natural groups are characterized by:

options.B: Unplanned gatherings, mutual attraction or perceived needs

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Unplanned gatherings, mutual attraction or perceived needs

**Why this is correct:** Understanding the difference between groups that form naturally (like friends) versus groups that are created by someone else (like therapy groups) helps social workers use the right approach for each type.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (External influence and structured meetings) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Professional facilitation and formal goals) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Agency sponsorship and formal membership) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Treatment groups primarily bond for:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Personal needs and common concerns

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Accomplishing organizational tasks) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Community development projects) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Administrative purposes) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Task groups gather to:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Accomplish a specific task

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Address personal therapy needs) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Provide emotional support only) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Form natural friendships) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

questions.question: When a group serves as a "medium of change," it means:

options.A: The group itself needs to be changed
options.B: The group influences a target member where the social worker guides processes
options.C: The group works on community issues
options.D: The group has no specific purpose

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - The group influences a target member where the social worker guides processes

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (The group itself needs to be changed) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (The group works on community issues) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (The group has no specific purpose) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Group as "target of change" refers to:

options.B: Changing aspects of the whole group like size, structure, procedures

questions.explanation:

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Individual member therapy) - This focuses on individuals rather than understanding how the whole group develops and changes.
• **C** (Community organizing) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (External advocacy work) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

options.B: The group actively works to effect changes in the environment

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (The worker changes the group) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Individual members change themselves) - This focuses on individuals rather than understanding how the whole group develops and changes.
• **D** (The agency changes its policies) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

questions.question: The Developmental Approach was primarily influenced by:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Emmanuel Tropp

**Why this is correct:** This approach sees groups as places where people can practice social skills and grow, like a safe practice space before facing real-world challenges.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Sigmund Freud) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **C** (Robert Vinter) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **D** (William Schwartz) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

• **D** (Unable to change) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.

questions.question: The Remedial Model was developed by:

**Why this is correct:** This approach focuses on changing specific problem behaviors through group influence, similar to how group therapy works to address particular issues.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Emmanuel Tropp) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **C** (William Schwartz) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **D** (Laura Epstein) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Group norms are:

options.B: Rules and standards of behavior that emerge in the group

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Rules and standards of behavior that emerge in the group

**Why this is correct:** Group norms are unwritten rules about behavior, like how families have their own ways of doing things. They help groups function smoothly.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Agency policies) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.
• **C** (Legal requirements) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.
• **D** (Individual preferences) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.

**Source:** Based on Toseland & Rivas group work principles (2017)

questions.question: Tuckman's stages of group development include all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: C** - Reforming

**Why this is correct:** Bruce Tuckman identified five specific stages that groups go through: forming, storming, norming, performing, and adjourning. Any other term is not part of his original model.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Forming) - This IS one of Tuckman's stages - the first stage where members get acquainted.
• **B** (Storming) - This IS one of Tuckman's stages - when conflicts and disagreements emerge.
• **D** (Performing) - This IS one of Tuckman's stages - the first stage where members get acquainted.

**Source:** Based on Bruce Tuckman's research on group development (1965)

questions.question: In Garland, Jones, and Kolodny's model, the "Power and Control" stage is characterized by:

options.B: Polarization over authority and competence of the worker

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Polarization over authority and competence of the worker

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Smooth cooperation) - This doesn't reflect how successful groups organize themselves and their activities.
• **C** (Complete harmony) - This doesn't reflect how successful groups organize themselves and their activities.
• **D** (Immediate productivity) - This doesn't reflect how successful groups organize themselves and their activities.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: The "Intimacy" stage in group development features:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Increased self-revelation and mutual support

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (High conflict) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Member withdrawal) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Power struggles) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: During the Separation phase, members typically experience:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Approach-avoidance patterns based on loss

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Joy only) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (No emotions) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Immediate acceptance) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Pre-termination activities include:

options.B: Working out difficult feelings and reviewing accomplishments

**Why the other options are wrong:**

• **D** (Avoiding discussion of ending) - Ignoring or avoiding issues is not an effective social work approach - problems need to be addressed directly.

questions.question: Maria, a social worker, is forming a support group for teenage mothers. During the first meeting, members are quiet and hesitant to share. What phase of group development is this?
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Pre-affiliation/Formation phase

**Why this is correct:** Bruce Tuckman's research shows that all groups go through predictable stages as they develop, just like how people grow from childhood to adulthood. This helps social workers know what to expect and how to help groups succeed.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Integration phase) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Intimacy phase) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Termination phase) - This describes the 'adjourning' stage, which is the final stage when groups end.

**Real-world example:** In a new support group for people dealing with grief, members might be quiet and polite at first, unsure about sharing personal feelings with strangers.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: In a substance abuse recovery group, Juan challenges the worker's authority and questions every suggestion. According to group development theory, this indicates:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Power and Control stage

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Pre-affiliation stage) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Intimacy stage) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Termination stage) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

options.B: Expected and should be addressed directly

questions.question: During group formation, members cannot agree on meeting times. The worker using a democratic approach should:

**Real-world example:** In a new support group for people dealing with grief, members might be quiet and polite at first, unsure about sharing personal feelings with strangers.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: In the Intimacy phase, members share deeply personal information. The worker's role is to:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Support while maintaining appropriate boundaries

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Stop such sharing) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Share equally personal information) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Record everything for agency files) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: A group approaching termination requests to continue meeting without the worker. This indicates:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Successful development of mutual aid

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Failure of the group) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Dependency issues) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Need for extended professional help) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: When conflict arises in a group, the Integrative conflict style emphasizes:

options.B: High concern for both goals and relationships

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - High concern for both goals and relationships

**Why this is correct:** Understanding how groups work helps social workers create positive environments where people can help each other.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (One party winning) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.
• **C** (Avoiding the conflict) - Ignoring or avoiding issues is not an effective social work approach - problems need to be addressed directly.
• **D** (Compromising values) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.

**Source:** Based on Toseland & Rivas group work principles (2017)

questions.question: A worker facilitating a group for caregivers of elderly parents notices exhaustion among members. The most appropriate program media would be:

options.B: Stress reduction activities and peer support

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Stress reduction activities and peer support

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Lengthy educational lectures) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Individual assignments) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Competitive games) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: During group formation, a member discloses they are only attending due to court mandate. The worker should:

options.B: Acknowledge this and work on finding mutual goals

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Acknowledge this and work on finding mutual goals

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Remove the member) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Ignore the disclosure) - Ignoring or avoiding issues is not an effective social work approach - problems need to be addressed directly.
• **D** (Report to the court immediately) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: A social worker notices that group cohesion is low after several sessions. According to group process theory, this might indicate:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Unresolved issues from earlier phases

**Why this is correct:** Group cohesion is like team spirit - when people feel connected to the group, they participate more and help each other succeed.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Need for immediate termination) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.
• **C** (Member pathology) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.
• **D** (Ineffective agency) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.

**Source:** Based on Toseland & Rivas group work principles (2017)

questions.question: In applying the Crisis Intervention Approach, the worker should prioritize:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Precipitating event and current coping

**Why this is correct:** Different group work approaches are like different tools - each one works best for specific situations and goals.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Deep psychological exploration) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **C** (Childhood history) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **D** (Long-term planning only) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: A member in a parenting group mentions using physical discipline. The worker should:

options.B: Address through education and group discussion

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Address through education and group discussion

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Ignore if not severe) - Ignoring or avoiding issues is not an effective social work approach - problems need to be addressed directly.
• **C** (Immediately report to authorities) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Remove from group) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: During evaluation, the worker finds that group goals were not met. This indicates:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Need for analysis and learning

**Why this is correct:** Professional ethics provide guidelines to ensure that social workers help people in ways that are safe, fair, and effective.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Complete failure) - This goes against professional social work standards and ethical guidelines.
• **C** (Member inadequacy) - This goes against professional social work standards and ethical guidelines.
• **D** (Agency failure) - This goes against professional social work standards and ethical guidelines.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: A social worker inheriting an ongoing group should first:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Assess current phase and dynamics

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Change everything immediately) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Start over with formation) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Terminate the group) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: When members miss sessions during the middle phase, this often indicates:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Resistance or unresolved conflicts

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Scheduling problems only) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Lack of commitment) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Need for individual therapy) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: The primary purpose of documentation in group work is:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Continuity of service and evaluation

**Why this is correct:** Professional ethics provide guidelines to ensure that social workers help people in ways that are safe, fair, and effective.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Agency protection) - This goes against professional social work standards and ethical guidelines.
• **C** (Legal requirements only) - This goes against professional social work standards and ethical guidelines.
• **D** (Research purposes) - This goes against professional social work standards and ethical guidelines.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards
